topics.title: Fundamental (base) units
topics.prompt: Can you recall and state the 7 fundamental SI units and their corresponding quantities (mass - kg, length - m, time - s, current - A, temperature - K, amount of substance - mol)? Can you distinguish them from derived units?

topics.title: Random and systematic errors

learningObjectives: Define random errors and their characteristics

Suggest methods to reduce random errors

examples: Random: Reading fluctuations in a digital voltmeter
Systematic: Zero error in a measuring instrument
Random reduction: Take multiple readings and average
Systematic reduction: Calibrate instruments, check zero errors

topics.title: Precision, accuracy, resolution

learningObjectives: Define precision in terms of consistency
Define accuracy in terms of closeness to true value
examples: High precision, low accuracy: Consistently wrong readings
High accuracy, low precision: Correct average, scattered readings

topics.title: Absolute and percentage uncertainties

learningObjectives: Calculate absolute uncertainty from repeated measurements
examples: Mean uncertainty: range/2 or standard deviation

topics.title: Combining uncertainties
topics.prompt: Do you know the rules for combining uncertainties? Can you correctly calculate the uncertainty in a final result when quantities are added, subtracted, multiplied, divided, or raised to a power?
learningObjectives: Apply rules for addition/subtraction of uncertainties
Apply rules for multiplication/division of uncertainties

Calculate final uncertainty in complex calculations

topics.title: Error bars and graph analysis

videos.title: 3.1.1 SI Base Units
videos.description: Understand the fundamental building blocks of all physical measurements. This section introduces the seven base units (like meters for length and kilograms for mass) that form the foundation of the International System of Units (SI). You'll also learn about derived units (like Newtons for force) and how to use prefixes to handle very large or small numbers.

videos.title: 3.1.1 SI Base Units
videos.description: Get a clear overview of the essential measurement concepts for your A-Level Physics course. This video covers the fundamental SI units, how other units are derived from them, and the common prefixes used in physics calculations.

videos.title: 3.1.1 SI Base Units
videos.description: Explore the basic 'dimensions' or types of quantities that physicists use to describe the world. This video helps you understand the difference between fundamental units in the SI and English systems, providing a solid conceptual base.

videos.title: 3.1.1 SI Base Units
videos.description: Learn how to correctly use the standard units and prefixes required for A-Level Physics. This video focuses on the practical application of SI units, ensuring you can confidently work with different scales of measurement.

videos.title: 3.1.1 SI Base Units
videos.description: This video explains the seven fundamental units of measurement and shows how more complex units like Newtons, Joules, and Watts are built from them, giving you practical examples to solidify your understanding.

videos.title: 3.1.2 Errors and Uncertainties
videos.description: Learn about the different types of errors that can occur in experiments and how to account for them. This series explains accuracy, precision, and how to calculate and combine uncertainties, which is a crucial skill for practical work.

videos.title: 3.1.2 Errors and Uncertainties
videos.description: This video breaks down how to handle uncertainties in your measurements, including how to calculate them from gradients on graphs and understand the difference between random and systematic errors.

videos.title: 3.1.2 Errors and Uncertainties
videos.description: Get a detailed look at how to calculate percentage uncertainties and combine errors from different measurements. This is essential for evaluating the reliability of your experimental results.

videos.title: 3.1.2 Errors and Uncertainties
videos.description: A comprehensive guide to measurement errors. This video covers everything from the basic types of errors to how to calculate and combine uncertainties, including using graphs to visualize them.

videos.title: 3.1.2 Errors and Uncertainties
videos.description: This lesson, created for the AQA curriculum, focuses on understanding and calculating errors and uncertainties, a key part of practical physics.

videos.title: 3.1.2 Errors and Uncertainties
videos.description: Learn how to calculate the uncertainty when you only have a single measurement, a common situation in practicals.

videos.title: 3.1.2 Errors and Uncertainties
videos.description: This video explains the concept of uncertainty in a simple way, making it easy to understand for your GCSE and A-Level studies.

videos.title: 3.2.1.1 Constituents of the atom
videos.description: Go back to the basics with this playlist that covers the fundamental parts of an atom (protons, neutrons, electrons), how we represent them, and the concepts of ions and isotopes.

videos.title: 3.2.1.1 Constituents of the atom
videos.description: This video gives a historical overview of how our model of the atom has changed over time, and explains the key concepts of atomic structure, isotopes, and the properties of subatomic particles.

videos.title: 3.2.1.1 Constituents of the atom
videos.description: Explore the structure of the atom, including the arrangement of electrons in energy levels and how this relates to the light emitted by atoms (spectral lines).

videos.title: 3.2.1.1 Constituents of the atom
videos.description: This video focuses on the key numbers used to describe atoms: the atomic number (protons) and mass number (protons + neutrons), and explains how these relate to an atom's overall charge.

videos.title: 3.2.1.1 Constituents of the atom
videos.description: A video specifically for the AQA curriculum that covers the essential knowledge about the building blocks of atoms, including nucleons, nuclide notation, and the concept of specific charge.

videos.title: 3.2.1.1 Constituents of the atom
videos.description: This lesson traces the development of the atomic model and covers the key constituents of the atom, mass and atomic numbers, specific charge, and isotopes.

videos.title: 3.2.1.2 Stable and unstable nuclei
videos.description: This revision video covers the entire topic of atomic structure and radiation for GCSE, which provides a great foundation for understanding why some atomic nuclei are stable and others are not.

videos.title: 3.2.1.2 Stable and unstable nuclei
videos.description: Explore what makes an atomic nucleus stable or unstable. This video discusses the different types of decay processes and the radiation they produce.

videos.title: 3.2.1.2 Stable and unstable nuclei
videos.description: This comprehensive one-hour review of AQA AS Physics includes a section on Particles & Quantum, which will cover the concepts of stable and unstable nuclei.

videos.title: 3.2.1.2 Stable and unstable nuclei
videos.description: A playlist dedicated to Nuclear Physics, covering the properties of stable and unstable nuclei and the processes of radioactive decay.

videos.title: 3.2.1.3 Particles
videos.description: This video introduces the concept of antimatter and explains the properties of antiparticles. It also covers the photon model of light, the Planck constant, and the processes of annihilation and pair production.

videos.title: 3.2.1.3 Particles
videos.description: Learn about the energy of a single photon and how it relates to the photoelectric effect. This video also touches on the fascinating concept of wave-particle duality.

videos.title: 3.2.1.3 Particles
videos.description: This video explains the concept of antimatter, the properties of antiparticles, the photon model of light, and how to calculate the energy of a photon.

videos.title: 3.2.1.3 Particles
videos.description: A clear explanation of what antiparticles are, with examples relevant to your AQA course.

videos.title: 3.2.1.3 Particles
videos.description: This video provides a detailed look at annihilation (when a particle and antiparticle meet) and pair production (when energy turns into a particle-antiparticle pair).

videos.title: 3.2.1.3 Particles
videos.description: A fun and comprehensive overview of particle physics, covering antiparticles, annihilation, pair production, and the fundamental forces.

videos.title: 3.2.1.4 Particle interactions
videos.description: This video covers the four fundamental forces of nature, the exchange particles that carry these forces, and how to represent these interactions using Feynman diagrams.

videos.title: 3.2.1.4 Particle interactions
videos.description: Learn how to draw Feynman diagrams for weak interactions (like beta decay) and electromagnetic interactions, and understand the conservation rules that govern them.

videos.title: 3.2.1.4 Particle interactions
videos.description: This video covers the fundamental forces and introduces the use of Feynman diagrams to visualize particle interactions.

videos.title: 3.2.1.4 Particle interactions
videos.description: This video explains the four fundamental interactions and their corresponding exchange particles, and shows how to draw Feynman diagrams for various processes.

videos.title: 3.2.1.4 Particle interactions
videos.description: An in-depth look at exchange particles (gauge bosons) and how to use Feynman diagrams to represent their interactions.

videos.title: 3.2.1.4 Particle interactions
videos.description: This video covers the fundamental forces and Feynman diagrams as part of a larger overview of particle physics.

videos.title: 3.2.1.5 Classification of particles
videos.description: Get an introduction to the Standard Model of particle physics. This video explains the different families of fundamental particles (bosons, leptons, quarks) and how they combine to form the particles we see.

videos.title: 3.2.1.5 Classification of particles
videos.description: This video explains how particles are classified based on their mass and how they interact with the strong nuclear force. You'll learn about hadrons (baryons and mesons) and leptons.

videos.title: 3.2.1.5 Classification of particles
videos.description: Learn about the different types of particles, including hadrons, mesons, leptons, and baryons, and the rules that govern their interactions.

videos.title: 3.2.1.5 Classification of particles
videos.description: This playlist provides a summary of particle classification and the important conservation laws you need to know.

videos.title: 3.2.1.5 Classification of particles
videos.description: This video covers the elementary particles of the Standard Model, including quarks, leptons, and the gauge bosons that mediate forces.

videos.title: 3.2.1.5 Classification of particles
videos.description: Learn about the important conservation laws in particle physics, including baryon number, lepton number, charge, and strangeness.

videos.title: 3.2.1.6 Quarks and antiquarks
videos.description: This video from the Standard Model series focuses on quarks, explaining their properties and how they combine to form protons, neutrons, pions, and kaons.

videos.title: 3.2.1.6 Quarks and antiquarks
videos.description: A focused video on quarks, detailing their properties and the specific combinations that make up common particles like protons and neutrons.

videos.title: 3.2.1.6 Quarks and antiquarks
videos.description: This video covers quarks as part of a larger overview of particle physics for A-level.

videos.title: 3.2.1.6 Quarks and antiquarks
videos.description: This video explains the concept of quarks and also demonstrates how beta decay can be understood as a transformation of one type of quark into another.

videos.title: 3.2.1.6 Quarks and antiquarks
videos.description: This video covers the elementary particles, including quarks, leptons, and gauge bosons, as part of the Standard Model.

videos.title: 3.2.1.6 Quarks and antiquarks
videos.description: A video specifically focused on how to describe different particles based on their quark make-up.

videos.title: 3.2.1.7 Applications of conservation laws
videos.description: Learn how to apply the fundamental conservation laws (charge, baryon number, lepton number, strangeness, energy, and momentum) to particle interactions. This video also explains why strangeness is not always conserved.

videos.title: 3.2.1.7 Applications of conservation laws
videos.description: This video explains how the conservation laws apply in both strong and weak interactions, with helpful examples to illustrate the concepts.

videos.title: 3.2.1.7 Applications of conservation laws
videos.description: A practical guide on how to use the conservation laws to determine whether a proposed particle interaction is actually possible.

videos.title: 3.2.1.7 Applications of conservation laws
videos.description: This video explains the conservation of charge, baryon number, lepton number, strangeness, energy, and momentum, with examples of different particle interactions.

videos.title: 3.2.1.7 Applications of conservation laws
videos.description: Learn how quantities like charge, baryon number, and lepton number are conserved in various particle interactions.

videos.title: 3.2.1.7 Applications of conservation laws
videos.description: This video discusses the conservation of baryon number, lepton number, charge, and strangeness, and importantly, notes that strangeness is only conserved in strong interactions.

videos.title: 3.2.2.1 The photoelectric effect
videos.description: This video explains the photoelectric effect, a key piece of evidence for the particle nature of light. It covers concepts like photon energy, work function, threshold frequency, and the famous photoelectric equation.

videos.title: 3.2.2.1 The photoelectric effect
videos.description: A video specifically on the photoelectric effect for A-level physics, explaining this important quantum phenomenon.

videos.title: 3.2.2.1 The photoelectric effect
videos.description: Learn about the photoelectric effect, where light can knock electrons out of a metal, providing strong evidence that light behaves as a particle (photon).

videos.title: 3.2.2.1 The photoelectric effect
videos.description: This video provides a clear explanation of the photoelectric equation and includes worked examples to help you solve problems.

videos.title: 3.2.2.1 The photoelectric effect
videos.description: This video demonstrates the particle nature of light using the photoelectric effect, showing how photons can transfer energy to electrons.

videos.title: 3.2.2.2 Collisions of electrons with atoms
videos.description: This video introduces the idea that electrons in atoms can only exist in specific, discrete energy levels. It explains the processes of excitation (moving to a higher level) and de-excitation (moving to a lower level).

videos.title: 3.2.2.2 Collisions of electrons with atoms
videos.description: Learn about what happens when electrons collide with atoms, leading to either ionization (the atom loses an electron) or excitation (an electron moves to a higher energy level).

videos.title: 3.2.2.2 Collisions of electrons with atoms
videos.description: This video covers energy levels within atoms and how they relate to the emission of light, which is caused by electron collisions and de-excitation.

videos.title: 3.2.2.2 Collisions of electrons with atoms
videos.description: This video explains the concept of ions, which are formed when atoms lose or gain electrons ‚Äì a direct result of collisions.

videos.title: 3.2.2.3 Energy levels and photon emission
videos.description: This video explains how electrons transitioning between discrete energy levels in an atom result in the emission of photons of specific energies, creating line spectra.

videos.title: 3.2.2.3 Energy levels and photon emission
videos.description: Learn how the existence of line spectra (the unique pattern of light emitted by different elements) provides direct evidence for discrete energy levels in atoms.

videos.title: 3.2.2.3 Energy levels and photon emission
videos.description: This video covers the relationship between electron energy levels and the emission of light, explaining how unique emission spectra are produced.

videos.title: 3.2.2.3 Energy levels and photon emission
videos.description: This video explains the formula for the allowed energy levels in an atom and how this is connected to the specific spectral lines that are observed.

videos.title: 3.2.2.4 Wave-particle duality
videos.description: This video addresses the core concept that particles like electrons can sometimes behave like waves, and waves like light can sometimes behave like particles.

videos.title: 3.2.2.4 Wave-particle duality
videos.description: This video discusses wave-particle duality in the context of photon energy and the photoelectric effect.

videos.title: 3.3.1.1 Progressive waves
videos.description: An introduction to mechanical waves, defining what they are and demonstrating that while they transfer energy, the medium itself does not travel along with the wave.

videos.title: 3.3.1.1 Progressive waves
videos.description: This video covers the basics of waves, including the difference between transverse and longitudinal waves, and introduces the electromagnetic spectrum.

videos.title: 3.3.1.1 Progressive waves
videos.description: Learn how waves transfer energy without transferring matter, using clear examples like springs and water waves. This video also defines key terms like frequency and period.

videos.title: 3.3.1.1 Progressive waves
videos.description: This video provides an introduction to the general concepts of waves, forming a good starting point for this topic.

videos.title: 3.3.1.2 Longitudinal and transverse waves
videos.description: This video defines both longitudinal and transverse waves, explaining the key difference in how the particles oscillate relative to the direction of energy transfer. It also introduces polarization as a property of transverse waves.

videos.title: 3.3.1.2 Longitudinal and transverse waves
videos.description: Practice your understanding with past paper questions focused on longitudinal and transverse waves.

videos.title: 3.3.1.2 Longitudinal and transverse waves
videos.description: This video defines longitudinal waves (with compressions and rarefactions) and transverse waves (with side-to-side or up-and-down wiggles) and explains how they transfer energy.

videos.title: 3.3.1.2 Longitudinal and transverse waves
videos.description: Using graphs of mechanical waves, this video demonstrates the concepts of longitudinal and transverse waves, wavelength, and period.

videos.title: 3.3.1.2 Longitudinal and transverse waves
videos.description: This video explains both types of waves and introduces polarization, the process of making a transverse wave oscillate in only one plane.

videos.title: 3.3.1.2 Longitudinal and transverse waves
videos.description: This video emphasizes the key concept that the matter or medium that a wave travels through does not move along with the wave itself.

videos.title: 3.3.1.3 Principle of superposition of waves and formation of stationary waves
videos.description: This video explains the principle of superposition ‚Äì what happens when two waves meet. It then details how stationary waves are formed from two identical waves traveling in opposite directions, creating points of no displacement (nodes) and maximum displacement (antinodes).

videos.title: 3.3.1.3 Principle of superposition of waves and formation of stationary waves
videos.description: This video explains the different phase relationships that occur within a stationary wave.

videos.title: 3.3.1.3 Principle of superposition of waves and formation of stationary waves
videos.description: This video demonstrates both constructive (waves adding up) and destructive (waves cancelling out) interference, which is the basis of superposition.

videos.title: 3.3.1.3 Principle of superposition of waves and formation of stationary waves
videos.description: This video covers the foundational concepts of wave superposition and how it leads to the formation of stationary waves.

videos.title: 3.3.1.3 Principle of superposition of waves and formation of stationary waves
videos.description: Learn about stationary waves, nodes, and antinodes, and see how these concepts apply to musical instruments.

videos.title: 3.3.2.1 Interference
videos.description: This video explains how interference patterns are created by coherent waves (waves with a constant phase relationship).

videos.title: 3.3.2.1 Interference
videos.description: This video explains how interference patterns arise from the superposition of overlapping waves.

videos.title: 3.3.2.1 Interference
videos.description: This video covers the essential concepts of superposition, coherence, path difference, and phase difference, which are all crucial for understanding interference.

videos.title: 3.3.2.1 Interference
videos.description: This video explains how interference patterns are produced by different types of waves (lasers, sound, microwaves) and includes important safety information for using lasers.

videos.title: 3.3.2.1 Interference
videos.description: This playlist includes videos on Young's Double Slit Experiment and Two Source Interference, which are classic examples of this phenomenon.

videos.title: 3.3.2.1 Interference
videos.description: Learn about the interference patterns created with both white light and laser light in Young's Double Slit experiment, including important laser safety precautions.

videos.title: 3.3.2.1 Interference
videos.description: This video provides examples and practice problems for Young's Double Slit Experiment, helping you to apply the concepts and equations.

videos.title: 3.3.2.2 Diffraction
videos.description: This video explains how a diffraction grating (a slide with many small slits) can be used to separate light and calculate the wavelength of the light.

videos.title: 3.3.2.2 Diffraction
videos.description: This video explains the derivation of the diffraction grating equation, a key formula for this topic.

videos.title: 3.3.2.2 Diffraction
videos.description: This video covers the effects of diffraction, which is the spreading out of waves as they pass through a gap or around an obstacle.

videos.title: 3.3.2.2 Diffraction
videos.description: This video provides examples and practice problems for single-slit diffraction.

videos.title: 3.3.2.2 Diffraction
videos.description: This video reviews the concept of diffraction and explains the diffraction grating equation.

videos.title: 3.3.2.2 Diffraction
videos.description: Test your knowledge with a past paper question on diffraction gratings.

videos.title: 3.3.2.3 Refraction at a plane surface
videos.description: This video explains how light changes speed and direction (bends) when it travels from one material to another. It defines the refractive index, explains Snell's Law, and covers total internal reflection.

videos.title: 3.3.2.3 Refraction at a plane surface
videos.description: This video explains that refraction is the change in a wave's direction when it enters a new medium at an angle, causing its speed to change.

videos.title: 3.4.1.1 Scalars and vectors
videos.description: This video introduces and explains the difference between scalars (quantities with magnitude only, like speed) and vectors (quantities with both magnitude and direction, like velocity). It also covers how to add and resolve vectors.

videos.title: 3.4.1.1 Scalars and vectors
videos.description: A helpful guide to understanding the key concepts of scalars and vectors.

videos.title: 3.4.1.1 Scalars and vectors
videos.description: This video provides an introduction to the basics of vectors, which are essential for describing motion and forces.

videos.title: 3.4.1.1 Scalars and vectors
videos.description: Part of a mechanics series, this video covers the fundamentals of scalars and vectors.

videos.title: 3.4.1.1 Scalars and vectors
videos.description: This video provides clear explanations and examples to help you distinguish between scalar and vector quantities.

videos.title: 3.4.1.2 Moments
videos.description: This video introduces the principle of moments and shows you how to calculate the turning effect of a force, even when it acts at an angle. It also explains the conditions for rotational equilibrium.

videos.title: 3.4.1.2 Moments
videos.description: A comprehensive video that describes and provides examples of moments, couples (pairs of forces), and the concept of toppling.

videos.title: 3.4.1.2 Moments
videos.description: This video on moments is part of a larger series on work, energy, and power.

videos.title: 3.4.1.2 Moments
videos.description: Part of a mechanics series, this video covers the concept of moments.

videos.title: 3.4.1.2 Moments
videos.description: This video provides explanations and examples to help you understand and calculate moments.

videos.title: 3.4.1.3 Motion along a a straight line
videos.description: This video addresses the topic of motion in a straight line, a fundamental part of mechanics.

videos.title: 3.4.1.4 Projectile motion
videos.description: This video explains how to solve problems involving objects fired at an angle by breaking the motion down into independent horizontal and vertical components and using the SUVAT equations.

videos.title: 3.4.1.4 Projectile motion

videos.title: 3.4.1.4 Projectile motion
videos.description: This video covers the key concepts of projectile motion, which is a classic topic in A-level physics.

videos.description: A dedicated playlist covering Newton's Laws and the related concept of momentum.

videos.title: 3.4.1.5 Newton's laws of motion
videos.description: This video covers Newton's laws of motion, a cornerstone of mechanics.

videos.title: 3.4.1.6 Momentum
videos.description: This video introduces and defines linear momentum as the product of an object's mass and velocity.

videos.title: 3.4.1.6 Momentum
videos.description: This video covers the definition of momentum, the principle of conservation of momentum, and how to perform calculations for collisions in one dimension.

videos.title: 3.4.1.6 Momentum
videos.description: A comprehensive video covering the topic of momentum for both GCSE and A-level physics.

videos.title: 3.4.1.6 Momentum
videos.description: An introduction to momentum, force, Newton's Second Law, and the conservation of linear momentum, with explanations and examples.

videos.title: 3.4.1.7 Work
videos.description: This video introduces and explains power as the rate at which work is done or energy is transferred.

videos.title: 3.4.1.7 Work
videos.description: This video covers the related concepts of work, energy, and power.

videos.title: 3.4.1.7 Work
videos.description: A full course covering the concepts of work, energy, and power, including elastic potential energy.

videos.title: 3.4.1.8 Conservation of energy
videos.description: This video introduces the principle of conservation of energy with a simple example of potential energy being converted into kinetic energy.

videos.title: 3.4.1.8 Conservation of energy
videos.description: This video states the law of conservation of energy: energy cannot be created or destroyed, only transferred from one form to another.

videos.title: 3.4.1.8 Conservation of energy
videos.description: This video covers the fundamental principle of the conservation of energy.

videos.title: 3.4.2.1 Bulk properties of solids
videos.description: This video covers the key properties of solid materials, including density, Hooke's Law, stress, strain, and the difference between plastic and brittle behaviour.

videos.title: 3.4.2.1 Bulk properties of solids
videos.description: This video covers the bulk properties of solids, an important topic in the materials section of the course.

videos.title: 3.4.2.1 Bulk properties of solids
videos.description: This video on elastic potential energy is part of a larger series on work, energy, and power, and is relevant to the study of how solids store energy when deformed.

videos.title: 3.4.2.2 The Young modulus

videos.description: This video covers the fundamental definitions of electric current and potential difference (voltage).

videos.title: 3.5.1.1 Basics of electricity
videos.description: This video covers the basics of electricity, a core topic in the A-level syllabus.

videos.description: This video covers the current-voltage (I-V) graphs for different electrical components, showing how their resistance changes with voltage.

videos.description: This video covers the I-V characteristics of components, a key part of understanding circuits.

videos.description: This video introduces and explains resistivity, a property of a material that determines how much it resists the flow of electric current.

videos.description: This video explains how to design an experiment to measure the resistivity of a material.

videos.description: This video covers the concept of resistivity and its importance in understanding the resistance of different materials.

videos.title: 3.5.1.4 Circuits
videos.description: This video introduces potential divider circuits, which are used to provide a specific fraction of a supply voltage and are often used in sensing circuits with thermistors or LDRs.

videos.description: This comprehensive revision video covers all of electrical circuits, including how to combine resistors in series and parallel and how to apply Kirchhoff's laws to analyze circuits.

videos.title: 3.5.1.4 Circuits
videos.description: This video covers the fundamentals of electrical circuits.

videos.title: 3.5.1.5 Potential divider
videos.description: This video introduces potential divider circuits and explains how they can be used to split a potential difference. It also shows how they are used in sensing circuits with components like thermistors and LDRs.

videos.title: 3.5.1.5 Potential divider
videos.description: This video demonstrates how a potential divider circuit with a thermistor or LDR can be used as a temperature or light sensor, as the output voltage changes with the resistance of the component.

videos.title: 3.5.1.5 Potential divider
videos.description: This video covers the use of potential dividers in circuits.

videos.description: This video covers the basics of electromotive force (emf) ‚Äì the total energy supplied by a power source per unit charge ‚Äì and explains how to find the internal resistance of a cell or battery.

videos.description: This video introduces internal resistance as a property of all power sources and explains how to measure and calculate it.

videos.description: This video covers the important concepts of emf and internal resistance.

revisionsections.title: SI Units and Measurements
revisionsections.notes_html:
Key Concepts

The International System of Units (SI) provides a consistent framework for scientific measurement. Understanding the seven base units is fundamental to all physics calculations.

The Seven SI Base Units

  • Length: metre (m) - defined by the distance light travels in vacuum in 1/299,792,458 seconds
  • Mass: kilogram (kg) - defined by Planck's constant
  • Time: second (s) - defined by cesium-133 atomic transitions
  • Electric Current: ampere (A) - defined by elementary charge
  • Temperature: kelvin (K) - defined by Boltzmann constant
  • Amount of Substance: mole (mol) - defined by Avogadro constant
  • Luminous Intensity: candela (cd) - defined by luminous efficacy
revisionsections.key_formulas: Standard form: a √ó 10‚Åø where 1 ‚â§ a < 10|Unit conversion: new value = old value √ó conversion factor
revisionsections.common_mistakes: Confusing mass (kg) with weight (N)|Incorrect prefix conversions|Not using standard form appropriately

revisionsections.title: Errors and Uncertainties
revisionsections.notes_html:
Key Concepts

Understanding and quantifying uncertainties is crucial for reliable scientific measurements. Errors can be systematic or random, and each requires different treatment.

Types of Errors

  • Systematic Errors: Consistent bias in measurements due to faulty equipment or method
  • Random Errors: Unpredictable variations in repeated measurements

Uncertainty Calculations

  • Absolute uncertainty: ¬±value in same units as measurement
  • Percentage uncertainty: (uncertainty/measurement) √ó 100%
  • Combining uncertainties follows specific rules for different operations
revisionsections.key_formulas: Addition/subtraction: add absolute uncertainties|Multiplication/division: add percentage uncertainties|Powers: multiply percentage uncertainty by the power
revisionsections.common_mistakes: Mixing absolute and percentage uncertainties|Not considering significant figures|Forgetting to square uncertainties when squaring quantities

revisionsections.title: Estimation and Orders of Magnitude
revisionsections.notes_html:
Key Concepts

Order of magnitude estimates help develop physical intuition and check the reasonableness of calculations.

Estimation Techniques

  • Round numbers to nearest power of 10
  • Break complex problems into simpler components
  • Use known reference values
  • Check final answers for physical reasonableness
revisionsections.key_formulas: Order of magnitude: express as 10‚Åø|Estimation: use powers of 10 and known values
revisionsections.common_mistakes: Being too precise in estimates|Not checking reasonableness of final answers|Forgetting to convert to appropriate units
